clean_story:
Group decisions. No leader.
Swarm intelligence describes how simple, unguided individuals—like ants or fish—create smart solutions together.


Picture a school of fish dodging a shark.
No single fish plans the move.
Each follows two rules: stay close, but don’t bump.
The result? A flash of silver that confuses predators.

Ants do this too.
A single ant is clumsy, but a colony builds bridges with their bodies to cross gaps.
No boss gives orders.
They rely on pheromones—chemical signals—to mark paths.
If food runs out, the trail fades, and ants switch routes without discussion.

Humans borrow this idea.
Robot swarms inspect pipelines, using the same "follow the crowd" logic.
Traffic apps route cars like ants, updating paths when roads jam.

Simple rules.
No commanders.
Just tiny actions adding up to something no one individual could design.

Emergent behavior.
Decentralized networks.
Collective robotics.
